newsitem.title: GERMANY: German net trade income falls in June - Buba.
newsitem.headline: German net trade income falls in June - Buba.

text.p: A fall in invisible transactions helped trim Germany's current account deficit in June although net income from foreign trade fell to a real six billion marks from 8.4 billion marks in May, the Bundesbank said on Thursday.
The Federal Statistical Office reported on September 10 that the deficit in June fell to 2.1 billion marks from 2.5 million in May.
"Exports have increased slightly, but the simultaneous rise in imports made a stronger impact," the Bundesbank said.
The central bank also said that in July, net inflows to German securities fell to 5.4 billion marks from a net 16 billion in June.
The Bundesbank said foreign interest in German securities, especially fixed income, remained high in July with inflows at 15 billion marks, up from 14.8 billion in the previous month.
However domestic investors also increased their investments in foreign securities to a net 9.6 billion marks after seliing 1.2 billion marks in June.
The Bundesbank's net external assets rose by 600 million marks in June and fell by 2.7 billion marks in July.
The statement said the drop was caused by foreign central banks buying back ECUs which the Bundesbank had acquired as part of its intervention activities in the European Monetary System.
